headline: Block Set to Join S&P 500
summary: Block Inc. (NYSE: XYZ) will replace Hess Corp. (NYSE: HES) in the S&P 500 effective prior to the opening of trading on Wednesday, July 23. S&P 500 and S&P 100 constituent Chevron Corp. (NYSE: CVX) has acquired Hess Corp in a deal that closed today, July 18.

headline: Heard on the Street Recap: Down Stream
summary: Chevron closed its $53 billion acquisition of Hess.  The move came swiftly after an international court cleared a bid by Exxon Mobil to derail the deal.  Shares of Chevron fell nearly 1% and Exxon was down 3.5%.

headline: Stock Market Today: Stocks Fall As Google, Tesla Earnings Loom; Netflix Dives On Results (Live Coverage)
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average pared its losses but couldn't get out of negative ground Friday as tariff concerns resurfaced with President Donald Trump reportedly pushing for steeper levies from the European Union.  Decliners on the stock market today included American Express while Google-parent Alphabet managed some gains.  The blue-chip index had stumbled by more than 200 points earlier after the Financial Times reported that Trump wants a minimum tariff of 15% to 20% on EU goods brought into U.S. The report, citing unnamed sources, said a 10% tariff on most items had been part of discussions regarding a framework trade agreement.

headline: Analysis-Chevron wins Exxon case but loses time, oil and billions
summary: (Reuters) -Exxon Mobil has lost its arbitration challenge to block Chevron's $55 billion Hess acquisition deal, but the top U.S. oil producer managed to delay the tie-up by over a year, costing its rival billions in lost Guyana oil revenue and slowing integration.  Chevron's deal, first announced in October 2023, closed on Friday after a drawn-out dispute over Hess's 30% stake in Guyana's Stabroek block, the most attractive asset in its portfolio.  The offshore oilfield holds more than 11 billion barrels of oil and is one of the fastest-growing oil production regions in the world.

raw.headline: Analysis-Chevron wins Exxon case but loses time, oil and billions
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Exxon Mobil has lost its arbitration challenge to block Chevron's $55 billion Hess acquisition deal, but the top U.S. oil producer managed to delay the tie-up by over a year, costing its rival billions in lost Guyana oil revenue and slowing integration.  Chevron's deal, first announced in October 2023, closed on Friday after a drawn-out dispute over Hess's 30% stake in Guyana's Stabroek block, the most attractive asset in its portfolio.  The offshore oilfield holds more than 11 billion barrels of oil and is one of the fastest-growing oil production regions in the world.

headline: Chevron closes Hess acquisition after winning Exxon legal battle
summary: STORY: Chevron sealed the deal for its $55 billion takeover of Hess on Friday, giving the energy giant access to the largest oil discovery in decades.Chevron completed the acquisition after winning a landmark legal battle against its larger rival Exxon Mobil, which had challenged the deal over rights to the Stabroek Block off the coast of Guyana.Exxon argued it had a pre-emptive right to buy Hess' stake in the lucrative offshore oil project, which holds more than 11 billion barrels of oil and is one of the fastest-growing sources of oil in the world.But the International Chamber of Commerce, the court that oversaw the case, ruled in favor of Chevron, and there is no appeals process.Stewart Glickman is an energy equity analyst at CFRA."Now that it's been decided, I think this is a shot in the arm for Chevron's, call it, medium-term production growth prospects because now it has acquired, among other things, the crown jewel, which is Guyana, 30% stake in this offshore oil project that has been throwing off a tremendous amount of production growth over the last couple of years and there are more phases to come that should also drive more incremental growth."Chevron CEO Mike Wirth's strategy to turn around his company's lagging performance hinged on the Hess acquisition, which had been delayed for over a year due to the high-stakes legal dispute.He said in a statement, quote, “This merger of two great American companies brings together the best in the industry.”Reuters previously reported that even as Chevron awaited the arbitration verdict, it was making preparations so it could close the deal with Hess quickly.Wirth said in an interview with Reuters on Friday that converting technology and combining employees from both companies would take a few months.Shares of Chevron were down about a percent in midday Friday trading while Exxon fell more than 3%.

raw.headline: Chevron closes Hess acquisition after winning Exxon legal battle
raw.summary: STORY: Chevron sealed the deal for its $55 billion takeover of Hess on Friday, giving the energy giant access to the largest oil discovery in decades.Chevron completed the acquisition after winning a landmark legal battle against its larger rival Exxon Mobil, which had challenged the deal over rights to the Stabroek Block off the coast of Guyana.Exxon argued it had a pre-emptive right to buy Hess' stake in the lucrative offshore oil project, which holds more than 11 billion barrels of oil and is one of the fastest-growing sources of oil in the world.But the International Chamber of Commerce, the court that oversaw the case, ruled in favor of Chevron, and there is no appeals process.Stewart Glickman is an energy equity analyst at CFRA."Now that it's been decided, I think this is a shot in the arm for Chevron's, call it, medium-term production growth prospects because now it has acquired, among other things, the crown jewel, which is Guyana, 30% stake in this offshore oil project that has been throwing off a tremendous amount of production growth over the last couple of years and there are more phases to come that should also drive more incremental growth."Chevron CEO Mike Wirth's strategy to turn around his company's lagging performance hinged on the Hess acquisition, which had been delayed for over a year due to the high-stakes legal dispute.He said in a statement, quote, “This merger of two great American companies brings together the best in the industry.”Reuters previously reported that even as Chevron awaited the arbitration verdict, it was making preparations so it could close the deal with Hess quickly.Wirth said in an interview with Reuters on Friday that converting technology and combining employees from both companies would take a few months.Shares of Chevron were down about a percent in midday Friday trading while Exxon fell more than 3%.

headline: Chevron entry to Guyana oilfields solves company's top challenge
summary: HOUSTON (Reuters) -Chevron’s imminent entry into Guyana’s rich offshore oilfields solves one of the biggest problems dogging the U.S. major: where its growth will come from beyond the next few years.  On Friday, the U.S. oil producer closed its $55-billion acquisition of Hess - among the largest ever oil and gas deals - and gained the latter's stake in Guyana's Stabroek Block after prevailing in a legal fight against larger rival Exxon Mobil.  Before the deal closed, concerns had been rising about Chevron's financial and production growth prospects, with its reserves of oil and gas dropping to the lowest in at least a decade.

raw.headline: Chevron entry to Guyana oilfields solves company's top challenge

On Friday, the U.S. oil producer closed its $55-billion acquisition of Hess - among the largest ever oil and gas deals - and gained the latter's stake in Guyana's Stabroek Block after prevailing in a legal fight against larger rival Exxon Mobil.  Before the deal closed, concerns had been rising about Chevron's financial and production growth prospects, with its reserves of oil and gas dropping to the lowest in at least a decade.

headline: Analysts on Chevron winning arbitration over Exxon in Hess deal
summary: Chevron closed its $55 billion acquisition of Hess on Friday after winning a landmark legal battle against larger rival Exxon Mobil to gain access to the biggest oil discovery in decades - the Stabroek Block off the coast of Guyana, which holds more than 11 billion barrels of oil. STEWART GLICKMAN, DEPUTY RESEARCH DIRECTOR AT CFRA RESEARCH "We see this transformative project driving meaningful production growth for at least the next three to five years, adding substantial new heft on the liquids side from Guyana, the Permian, and Gulf of Mexico. CVX and XOM must now put this legal dispute behind them as partners in Guyana, with the focus turning to advancing planned development stages."

raw.headline: Analysts on Chevron winning arbitration over Exxon in Hess deal
raw.summary: Chevron closed its $55 billion acquisition of Hess on Friday after winning a landmark legal battle against larger rival Exxon Mobil to gain access to the biggest oil discovery in decades - the Stabroek Block off the coast of Guyana, which holds more than 11 billion barrels of oil. STEWART GLICKMAN, DEPUTY RESEARCH DIRECTOR AT CFRA RESEARCH "We see this transformative project driving meaningful production growth for at least the next three to five years, adding substantial new heft on the liquids side from Guyana, the Permian, and Gulf of Mexico. CVX and XOM must now put this legal dispute behind them as partners in Guyana, with the focus turning to advancing planned development stages."

headline: Fed rate debate, GENIUS Act passes, Chevron-Hess deal: 3 Things
summary: Here are some of the stories Wall Street is watching on Friday, July 18. Federal Reserve governor Christopher Waller argued the central bank should cut rates in July, pitting him against other members who think the Fed should wait to cut. The GENIUS Act, a bill to regulate stablecoins, was passed by the US House of Representatives. President Trump is scheduled to sign the bill into law Friday afternoon. Chevron (CVX) received the green light to move ahead with its $53 billion acquisition of Hess (HES). The International Chamber of Commerce decided against ExxonMobil (XOM), which had challenged the deal over Hess's assets in Guyana. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

headline: Chevron gets go ahead for $53B Hess deal, and access to one of the biggest oil finds this decade
summary: Chevron has scored a critical ruling in Paris that has given it the go-ahead for a $53 billion acquisition of Hess and access to one of the biggest oil finds of the decade.  Chevron said Friday that it completed its acquisition of Hess shortly after the ruling from the International Chamber of Commerce in Paris.  Exxon had challenged Chevron’s bid for Hess, one of three companies with access to the massive Stabroek Block oil field off the coast of Guyana.
